Ryan Cueto Duquitan (applicant) v. The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (respondent)
(IMM-7812-14; DATE_SUPPRESSED FC 769; DATE_SUPPRESSED CF 769)
Indexed As: Duquitan v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration)
Cite As: [DATE_SUPPRESSED] F.T.R. Uned. 359
Federal Court
Shore, J.
June 19, DATE_SUPPRESSED.
Counsel:
Nduka Ahanonu, for the applicant, Ryan Cueto Duquitan;
Brad Hardstaff, for the respondent, Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.
Solicitors of Record:
Duke Law Office, Edmonton, Alberta, for the applicant, Ryan Cueto Duquitan;
William F. Pentney, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Edmonton, Alberta, for the respondent, Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.
I.
Overview

[1]
Shore, J.
: "The Court finds that the discovery of marital infidelity is relevant to the determination of whether marriage between the applicant and the sponsor is genuine. ... The factors relevant to this determination include the existence of monogamy and a commitment to exclusivity."

[2]
The core matter is one of spousal sponsorship as is stated in the decision of Mr. Justice Michael Kelen, as quoted above (
REFERENCE_SUPPRESSED).

[3]
In addition, "the word 'conjugal' does not mean sexual relations alone. It signifies that there is a significant degree of attachment between two partners. The word 'conjugal' comes from two Latin words, one meaning 'join' and the other meaning 'yoke,' thus, literally, the term means 'joined together' or 'yoked together'." (As is stated in CIC's Operation Manual,
OP2: Processing Members of the Family Class
(the Manual)). It is recalled that it is of paramount importance in such a determination that the existence of monogamy and commitment to exclusivity in a marriage is primordial.
II.
Background

[4]
The Applicant seeks judicial review pursuant to section 72(1) of the
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
, SC 2001, c 27 [IRPA] of an Immigration Appeal Division [IAD] decision upholding the Immigration Division's [ID] issuance of an exclusion order against the Applicant for having withheld a material fact relating to a relevant matter that induced or could have induced an error in the administration of the IRPA, under paragraph 40(1) of the IRPA.

[5]
The Applicant is a 30 year old citizen of the Philippines. The Applicant was sponsored by his ex-wife [M.F.D] and became a permanent resident of Canada on September 16, 2010. Shortly thereafter, M.F.D. learned that the Applicant was in a continuing relationship with another woman [A.G.]. M.F.D. left the Applicant and reported his actions to the Canada Border Services Agency [CBSA]. As a result of his failure to disclose his extramarital relationship, the Applicant was found to be inadmissible under paragraph 40(1)(a) of the IRPA. As a result, an exclusion order was issued against the Applicant pursuant to subsection 45(d) of the IRPA. On appeal before the IAD, the Applicant challenged the legal validity of the exclusion order pursuant to the IAD's discretionary jurisdiction to grant special relief on the basis of H&C grounds.

[6]
In its decision, dated September 22, 2014, the IAD assessed the materiality of the Applicant's non-disclosure of his intimate relationship with A.G., with whom he had an intimate and public relationship that he attempted to conceal from M.D.F. The IAD concluded that the Applicant's relationship with A.G. was a material fact related to a relevant matter in that it goes to the very core of the genuineness of the Applicant's marriage with his sponsor, M.D.F. The IAD reasoned that by withholding the facts related to his relationship with A.G., the Applicant averted further enquiries by the visa officer, thereby inducing an error in the administration of the IRPA. Such as enunciated by Justice Michael A. Kelen of the Federal Court in
CITATION_SUPPRESSED
, "the discovery of marital infidelity is relevant to the determination of whether the marriage between the applicant and sponsor is genuine" (REFERENCE_SUPPRESSED).

[7]
Relying on Justice Robert Mainville's decision in
CITATION_SUPPRESSED
, the IAD further found that the Applicant had a general and broad duty to disclose all facts which may be material to his application for permanent residence (REFERENCE_SUPPRESSED). The IAD concluded that the Applicant knew or ought to have known that his application was contingent on the visa officer's determination that he was a member of the family class by virtue of his marriage to M.F.D.
III.
Analysis

[8]
The IAD's analysis and reasons pertaining to the validity of the exclusion order issued against the Applicant and the recognition of the Applicant's duty of candour owed towards Canadian immigration officials are thorough and anchored in the evidentiary record and the law. The Court finds that the IAD's conclusion that the Applicant's misrepresentation was at the heart of the determination of his spousal sponsorship for the purposes of subsection 40(1) of the IRPA is reasonable; had the Applicant not withheld the relationship with A.G., he likely would not have received a permanent resident visa as M.F.D.'s spouse.

[10]
This Court has held that the purpose of paragraph 40(1)(a) of the IRPA is to ensure that applicants provide "complete, honest and truthful information and to deter misrepresentation" and that "full disclosure is fundamental to the proper and fair administration of the immigration scheme". It has also been held that subsection 40(1) of the IRPA encompasses innocent failures to disclose material information. Moreover, "a misrepresentation need not be decisive or determinative to be material; it must only be important enough to affect the process" (REFERENCE_SUPPRESSED).
IV.
Conclusion

[11]
The Court finds that the IAD's conclusion, in respect of insufficient H&C considerations to warrant special relief in the circumstances, is reasonable. The IAD's findings pertaining to H&C considerations are anchored in the evidentiary records and are based on a careful consideration of the factors established in
CITATION_SUPPRESSED
, as stated above.

[12]
The Court, therefore, concludes that the application for judicial review is dismissed.
JUDGMENT

[13]
THIS COURT'S JUDGMENT is that
:
1. The application for judicial review is dismissed.
2. No serious question of general importance is certified.

 Remorse: the Applicant showed no remorse or understanding for the seriousness of his non-disclosure. Rather, the Applicant minimized his actions and provided misleading answers during his CBSA interview;
 Degree of establishment in Canada: the IAD found that the Applicant has established himself as a hard-working member of the community, which is a positive factor; however, but for his misrepresentation, the Applicant would not have achieved this level of establishment;
 Undue hardship upon return to the Philippines: the IAD found that other than a loss of income and a return to his former way-of-life, the Applicant's submission that the loss of his status in Canada would cause him or members of his family undue hardship is unsupported by the evidence. statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , SC 2001, c 27 [IRPA]
section 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
legal_issues: The scope of the duty to disclose material facts in immigration applications.
The materiality of non-disclosure of information regarding marital relationships in spousal sponsorship applications.
The standard of review applicable to immigration appeal division decisions regarding exclusion orders.
The assessment of humanitarian and compassionate considerations in the context of immigration inadmissibility.
The definition of 'genuine' marriage for immigration purposes and the relevance of marital fidelity to that determination.
The application of misrepresentation provisions in immigration law, including whether innocent omissions constitute misrepresentation.
The legal consequences of failing to disclose information that could have altered the outcome of an immigration application.
factual_background: An applicant, a citizen of the Philippines, obtained Canadian permanent residency through spousal sponsorship in 2010.
The applicant's sponsor subsequently discovered the applicant was in a relationship with another woman.
The sponsor reported the applicant's actions to the Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA).
The applicant was found inadmissible to Canada due to failure to disclose the extramarital relationship.
An exclusion order was issued against the applicant.
The applicant appealed the exclusion order to the Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), arguing on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
The IAD determined the undisclosed relationship was material to the genuineness of the marriage.
The IAD assessed the applicant's duty to disclose the relationship and found it was not fulfilled.
The IAD considered factors related to the applicant's establishment in Canada, potential hardship upon return to the Philippines, and family support.
The IAD ultimately denied the appeal, finding insufficient humanitarian and compassionate grounds for special relief.

Applicants: The Applicant challenged the legal validity of the exclusion order based on Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) grounds.
The Applicant claimed undue hardship would be suffered upon return to the Philippines, citing loss of income and a return to his former way of life.
The Applicant argued he financially supports his family in the Philippines by sending monthly remittances.
The Applicant asserted his establishment in Canada as a hard-working member of the community should be considered.
The Applicant minimized his actions and provided misleading answers during his CBSA interview (as noted by the IAD, but presented as part of the applicant's overall case).
The Applicant argued that the loss of status in Canada would affect his nieces and nephews who rely on his financial support.
Respondents: The Respondent maintained the Applicant withheld a material fact (the extramarital relationship with A.G.) relating to a relevant matter (the genuineness of his marriage to M.F.D.).

The Respondent argued the Applicant’s misrepresentation induced an error in the administration of the IRPA, as the visa officer would not have approved the application had the relationship been disclosed.
The Respondent asserted the Applicant had a general and broad duty to disclose all facts material to his application for permanent residence.
The Respondent submitted the Applicant showed no remorse or understanding for the seriousness of his non-disclosure.
The Respondent contended the Applicant’s claims of undue hardship upon return to the Philippines were unsupported by evidence.
The Respondent argued the Applicant’s claim of financial support to his family was unsupported by evidence.
The Respondent highlighted that the Applicant’s establishment in Canada was a direct result of the misrepresentation.

court_analysis: The court affirmed the IAD’s decision to uphold the exclusion order against the applicant, finding the IAD’s analysis thorough, reasonable, and well-supported by the evidentiary record and the law.

The court agreed with the IAD that the applicant’s failure to disclose his relationship with A.G. was a material misrepresentation because it went to the core of the genuineness of his marriage to his sponsor, M.F.D., and likely would have prevented him from obtaining permanent residency had it been disclosed.
The court adopted the principle that marital infidelity is relevant to determining the genuineness of a marriage for spousal sponsorship purposes, citing previous Federal Court decisions.
The court confirmed the applicant had a broad duty of candour to disclose all facts material to his application, relying on established jurisprudence.

The court upheld the IAD’s assessment of Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) considerations, finding it reasonable to conclude that insufficient H&C grounds existed to warrant special relief. The IAD properly considered factors like the seriousness of the misrepresentation, the applicant’s lack of remorse, his degree of establishment in Canada (which was contingent on the misrepresentation), and the unsupported claims of undue hardship upon return to the Philippines.

The court reiterated that the purpose of paragraph 40(1)(a) of the IRPA is to ensure complete honesty in applications and deter misrepresentation, and that even innocent failures to disclose material information can be grounds for inadmissibility.
The court affirmed that a misrepresentation does not need to be decisive to be material; it only needs to be important enough to affect the immigration process.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is dismissed.
No serious question of general importance is certified.
